results.justification: The paper clearly states its research methodology as developing and evaluating a novel course recommendation model (MAECR) using knowledge graphs and meta-paths.
Sections 4 (MAECR model introduction) and 5 (Experiment Setup) provide a step-by-step description of the study design, including model components, data preprocessing, and evaluation metrics.
The paper mentions the dataset is collected from the XuetangX MOOC and provides a link: http://www.xuetangx.com.
Data is mentioned as being available.

Table 1 provides statistics of the dataset, including the number of users, courses, knowledge entities, and relations. The text also describes the data preprocessing steps (filtering users and courses).
The paper states the data was collected from the XuetangX MOOC platform and describes the filtering criteria applied to the data.
The paper does not mention whether the analysis code is publicly available.
Code is not mentioned as being shared.
The paper does not explicitly state whether the data preparation code is shared.
The paper clearly describes the statistical tests and models used, including BPR loss function, LSTM, and attention mechanisms.
The paper reports performance metrics such as Precision@K, Recall@K, HR@K, and NDCG@K, which can be interpreted as effect sizes.
The study is primarily quantitative; subjective context and interpretation are limited.
Not applicable, as the study is not primarily qualitative.
Results are presented in tables (e.g., Table 2) and discussed in the text, with clear comparisons to baseline models.
The paper discusses limitations, such as the lack of real user experiments and the need for further evaluation on more datasets. It also acknowledges potential biases.
The paper does not contain a link to a preregistration.
